title: Jay Cowan
text:
Jay Marine Cowan (born July 31, 1946-January 23, 2022) was a <a href="politician">politician</a> in <a href="Manitoba">Manitoba</a>, Canada. He was a member of the <a href="Legislative%20Assembly%20of%20Manitoba">Legislative Assembly of Manitoba</a> from 1977 to 1990, and a <a href="Minister%20%28government%29">cabinet minister</a> in the government of <a href="Howard%20Pawley">Howard Pawley</a> from 1981 to 1988.
Cowan left the <a href="United%20States%20of%20America">United States of America</a> during the <a href="Vietnam%20War">Vietnam War</a> to avoid that nation's military draft. In Canada, he worked as a miner and organizer for the <a href="social%20democratic">social democratic</a> <a href="New%20Democratic%20Party%20of%20Manitoba">New Democratic Party</a>. He was a member of the <a href="United%20Steelworkers%20of%20America">United Steelworkers of America</a> during this period.
In 1977, Cowan was sent by <a href="Manitoba%20New%20Democratic%20Party">Manitoba NDP</a> leader <a href="Edward%20Schreyer">Edward Schreyer</a> to the northern <a href="electoral%20district%20%28Canada%29">riding</a> of <a href="Churchill%20%28Manitoba%20riding%29">Churchill</a> to scout for suitable candidates. Perhaps contrary to Schreyer's expectations, he secured the nomination for himself (despite the fact that he was not yet a Canadian citizen) and was duly returned in the <a href="1977%20Manitoba%20general%20election">general election</a> that followed, defeating <a href="Progressive%20Conservative%20Party%20of%20Manitoba">Progressive Conservative</a> Mark Ingebrigtson by about 300 votes.
In 1979, Cowan was one of the most prominent supporters of <a href="Howard%20Pawley">Howard Pawley</a> in the latter's successful bid to succeed Schreyer as party leader. Cowan was re-elected in the <a href="1981%20Manitoba%20general%20election">general election of 1981</a> (this time defeating Ingebrigtson by around 1350 votes); the NDP won the election, and he was appointed <a href="Manitoba%20Minister%20of%20Northern%20Affairs">Minister of Northern Affairs</a> on November 30, 1981, with responsibility for <a href="Environmental%20Management%20%28Manitoba%20ministry%29">Environmental Management</a>, the <a href="Clean%20Environment%20Act%20%28Manitoba%20ministry%29">Clean Environment Act</a>, the <a href="Workers%20Compensation%20Act%20%28Manitoba%20ministry%29">Workers Compensation Act</a>, the <a href="Workplace%20Safety%20and%20Health%20Act%20%28Manitoba%20ministry%29">Workplace Safety and Health Act</a>, and the <a href="Communities%20Economic%20Development%20Fund%20Act%20%28Manitoba%20ministry%29">Communities Economic Development Fund Act</a>.
Following a <a href="Cabinet%20%28government%29">cabinet</a> shuffle on November 4, 1983, Cowan was named <a href="Manitoba%20Minister%20of%20Co-operative%20Development">Minister of Co-operative Development</a> and <a href="Manitoba%20Chairman%20of%20the%20Treasury%20Board">Chairman of the Treasury Board</a>. He was again re-elected without difficulty in the <a href="1986%20Manitoba%20general%20election">general election of 1986</a>.
On April 17, 1986, Cowan was relieved of his position with the Treasury Board and was named government house leader. He continued to serve as Minister of Co-operative Development, and was also the <a href="Manitoba%20Minister%20of%20Native%20Affairs">Minister of Native Affairs</a> (without portfolio) responsible for the <a href="Natural%20Gas%20Supply%20Act%20%28Manitoba%20ministry%29">Natural Gas Supply Act</a> from September 21, 1987 to November 23, 1987.
The NDP were unexpectedly defeated in the legislature in 1988, after disgruntled backbencher <a href="Jim%20Walding">Jim Walding</a> voted with the opposition in a narrowly divided house. Cowan was one of only twelve New Democrats (in a 57-member house) to be returned in the <a href="1988%20Manitoba%20general%20election">1988 general election</a>. In opposition, he opposed the proposed labour reforms of <a href="Progressive%20Conservative%20Party%20of%20Manitoba">Progressive Conservative</a> <a href="Premier">Premier</a> <a href="Gary%20Filmon">Gary Filmon</a>. He chose not to seek re-election in 1990.
Cowan was director of special projects at the <a href="Anokiiwin%20Training%20Institute">Anokiiwin Training Institute</a>, working with aboriginal groups in Manitoba and northwestern <a href="Ontario">Ontario</a>. As of 2003, he was also the chair of the <a href="Manitoba%20Federation%20of%20Labour">Manitoba Federation of Labour</a>'s health and safety committee.
